awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: New Frontiers in Encryption Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Encryption is the process of encoding data into a ciphertext such that only the intended recipient can decode and learn the data. This project pushes the frontiers of what is achievable for encryption. The project's novelties are building encryption systems with advanced capabilities that have provable security under standard assumptions. These include the capability to trace malicious users who leak confidential information as well as the ability to only release select pieces of information to users on a need to know basis. The project's impacts are the development of a new generation of encryption systems that are built from reliable and tested mathematical underpinnings.

The project consists of three primary thrusts. (1) Chosen ciphertext security. Chosen ciphertext security (IND-CCA) is arguably the right notion of security both for traditional encryption systems as well as ones with advanced functionality. The investigators investigate generic methods and new tools for converting IND-CPA systems into IND-CCA ones.  (2) Tracing in encryption systems.  Traitor tracing is the problem of determining the source of a decoder box in a broadcast system.  The investigators explore challenging new problems including: getting trace and broadcast systems with N^{1/c} sized ciphertexts for any constant c, achieving public traceability for the same parameters and using tracing techniques as a tool for proving adaptive security. (3) New frontiers in encryption based on the Learning With Errors (LWE) assumption. Building from the LWE assumption is an exciting avenue for producing new functionality in cryptography from a well-studied assumption.  The investigators will pursue ambitious goals in this direction, including a new concept of obfuscating pseudorandom functionalities and its applications, as well as a program for constructing witness encryption from LWE beginning with an intermediate goal of building constrained pseudorandom functions for the bit fixing functionality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing new forms of advanced encryption systems that allow far greater functionality than standard public key encryption. Key outcomes include:

 

Introduction of the Registered Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE). In standard ABE an encryptor specifies a message and an access policy over the attributes of a user. The user can only decrypt if their key attributes match the policy of the ciphertext. However, all prior ABE systems required an authority with a master secret key to issue the keys. If the authority is ever hacked or corrupted all security is lost. In registered ABE the authority is only responsible for compiling the system’s parameters, but does not hold any master secret. In addition, to introducing the notion we provide an efficient construction from bilinear maps. 

 

We also showed new methods for building advanced encryption systems from a primitive known as witness encryption, which allows for encryption to NP statements. We provide several applications of this including showing how to build the above mentioned registered ABE from witness encryption. This gives us new and more general paths to building registered ABE. 

 

In addition to building encryption systems, this project made substantial contributions to building new proof systems. A  CRYPTO 2022 work showed the first batch argument system from bilinear maps (in the standard model). A batch argument system allows one to communicate the proofs of several statements in space that is proportional to just proving a single statement. Prior work did this from lattice assumptions. Here we introduced a different approach and did it from a new set of computational assumptions. The work was awarded the best paper award at the CRYPTO 2022 conference.

 

The award supported several Ph.D. students over its course. These Ph.D. students received mentoring from the PIs and published several papers at top venues over the course of the award. In addition, they gave talks both at the publication venues as well as invited talks. Finally, the PI was involved in initiating and organizing Texas Crypto Day, which brought together several cryptography researchers and students from Central Texas to an event consisting of talks and discussions. The event has occurred twice a year since its inception. 


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Brent R Waters
